You could almost make a case for soooooo many business being a pyramid scheme
Or at least just a pyramid hierarchy

Fun to break it down. I also see your point. 

It's the Kratom talking here ...

But I see the main difference as:

In evaluating similarities / differences between an entity that is purposefully a fraudulent 'pyramid scheme' organization...  and a non/fraudulent 'traditional business', it really just comes down to one thing...

being...

- does the entity in question offer a REAL product or REAL service, in which revenue is received by the company, from a fair market, in exchange for thr genuine product or service it distributes as the entity in question.

 ...meaning, if 'no' the entity does not and therefore offers a fake, fraudulent product or service..it's a pyramid scheme...

the other legitimate business (which mistakenly gets lumped in and compared to a fraudulent pyramid scheme company occurs only due to the company having a traditional, hierarchical organizational chart, aka an organizational structure of internal power ...it is simply shaped like a pyramid, yes, hence the understandable confusion)...though, however, it is not a pyramid scheme...and even with that org structure...the entity in this example is a NON-fraudulent company that offers real products and services. 

It's the incorrect perception of 'pyramid' that draws the alignment of the two companies, but its two different things really. One is the hierarchical shape and that alone...aka simply the shape of the organizational chart ...aka a top-down, vertical hierarchy of corporate power. 

The other ..much different 

Granted, people see the people on top winning in both examples ...and that drives the confusion deeper. 

Most likely a democrat barking about this stuff

In fraudulent pyramid business models, 'pyramid' solely represents the reliance on an ever increasing recruitment of new, non-employee participants to keep it going (reminds me of a reserve that MUST keep printing...or it dies!)

These entities in turn don't focus any effort on putting out an improved or competitive product or service...rather to thrive, the only focus required is to recruit more non-W2 participants and to build an internal incentive structure not individual hires who are there to sell and get paid for selling a real product, but the opposite. There is no real product, they are incentivized to print more recruits like themselves...on recruiting others like themselves, simply more people to drive people who pay to participate in the scheme, 

thus this is where a pyramid scheme makes its 'revenue ' - recruiting 1099 workers who pay the company to participate. Not revenue from sales of a genuine product or service...bc they ain't one).
The unfortunate grey area is any legitimate multi-level marketing (MLM) entity. They recruit and incentivize 1099 sellers who aren't traditionally a formal W2 employee...rather 1099 'contractors'

but MLMs have a genuine product or service for them sell (ex Amway). 

To further distinguish MLMs, commissions are based on sales of legit product or service, whereas pyramid schemes are incentivizing recruitment , not product/service sales.
But alas I'm am associated with non or the above
